head.supplied: Melbourne, 24th June, 1890. ¶ Sir— In reply to your kind letter dear Mr. Hodgkinson, ¶ Letter not found. ¶ let me say that I have now sufficient information about the Yellow Stringy Bark tree to reg...

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Letter not found. The text given here is from Clement Hodgkinson's report in Report of the Melbourne Harbour Trust Commissioners for the year 1890, p. 19 (B91.13.09). It was also published n 'Yellow string bark', Leader, 19 July 1890, p. 14 (B90.07.03). Hodgkinson's report was presented to the meeting of the Commissioners held on 9 July 1890 (Age, 10 July 1890, p. 7). Hodgkinson introduced M's letter by:
It is astonishing that this kind of eucalyptus has been so long unknown to Melbourne timber merchants and to botanists. Having corresponded with Baron von Mueller relative thereto, I received from him the following interesting letter, dated 24th ult:'.
Melbourne, 24th June, 1890.

p.seg: Sir— In reply to your kind letter dear Mr. Hodgkinson,

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: let me say that I have now sufficient information about the Yellow Stringy Bark tree to regard it as a distinct kind of tree.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Eucalyptus muelleriana was described and named in A. Howitt (1891), pp. 89-91, read at a meeting of the Royal Society of Victoria on 10 July 1890. Howitt (p. 91) states that he had compared specimens with those held by M and, 'fortified by the opinion of our greatest authority', was satisfied that it was distinct.

p.seg: I will let you know under what name it will be recorded in a few days.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: As Howitt had discussed the species with M it is likely that when he wrote to Hodgkinson M knew of the outlines of Howitt's description; he either did not know what name Howitt was using or, perhaps more likely, deferred reporting the name until the paper had been read, thus preserving Howitt's priority for the necessary 'few days'.

p.seg: As it is only known from three localities,
in none of which I have ever made a stay, I had formerly not so clear ideas about the distinctness of this Eucalyptus as now.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: M presumably obtained this information from Howitt, who specified the three localities in A. Howitt (1891).

p.seg: Have you any opportunity of getting any seeds of it secured, it being so valuable for timber purposes? I should be thankful of receiving your information on the specific strength and weight of this timber.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The report in the Leader included a table of results of tests of five samples of the timber, but Hodgkinson later sent a letter to the Editor correcting a typographical error in the description of the tests performed (Leader, 26 July 1890, p. 12).

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
